tweets.text:
*Cracks Knuckles

1. 2018 was peak nature and wilderness in my personal mythopoem. 

I spent 1.5 years living in Colorado.

Up until then & now I've always lived in cities >5 million people.

Nature and Wilderness forms a key political cornerstone for Americana consciousness. https://t.co/Q3tpxYdnlu

2. The American Pioneer. 

That sacrosanct motif of the White male American man conquering the savages of Nature & Wilderness has a deep political history and narrative that was carefully curated by an amalgam of capitalism and public policy. 

It reveals certain deep biases.

3. In my 13 years living amongst American culture and motifs, I've come to better understand what I call the Pioneer Bias that governs how many Americans think and yearn.

At the root of it is a desire to civilize, control, & conquer Nature and Wilderness

https://t.co/Z2zu6iEkw1

4. This differs significantly in how I interpreted my native culture's own relationship with Nature and Wilderness.

Civilization & Identity was part and parcel of Nature and Wilderness

My name is a reverence for Water and the Oceans

My mother: Ì†ºÌºï
My father: Ì†ºÌºû
Sister: Rain

5. Of course this is not to say that the American narrative is completely irreevential towards Nature & Wilderness.

The Great National Parks are a visible testament to America's commitment towards preservation.

https://t.co/JNT3qWgBeD

6. While the state of the Ganga and every other divinely named water body reflects the apathy of the Indian State that claims to be protectors of the Hindu condition. Some protection.

https://t.co/rSM4jfRdtI

7. Thoreau and Walden Pond formed for me the initial studies of how Nature and Wilderness serve to be cathartic to the Human condition. 

To Walden Pond is to retreat to Nature and Wilderness and recover from a perennial and unsustainable urban condition.

8. For a long time I held this view of Nature and Wilderness, it is something to retreat to, an instrument of escape.

John Belushi in Continental Divide was evidence of how this was comically wrong this notion can be.

https://t.co/1cw2MTLKlG

9. Nature and Wilderness 2x2.

Of Nature and Wild::Cannibalism)

Of Nature and Legible::Predator/Prey

Unnatural and Wild::Rabid?

Unnatural and Legible::Magnetism?
@Freakonomics {taking a break to go on a small hike}
@Freakonomics 12. The exile into the wild and away from humanity is also a key part of Moses' journey.

@Freakonomics 13. My earliest memory of a warm & fuzzy association with Wilderness is The Wind & the Willows.

It told the adventures of Badger, Rat, Toad, and Mole through the wilderness. 

Showed me that Wilderness and civilization could co-exist.

https://t.co/Cz7LODAMwu
@Freakonomics 14. Earliest scary memory of the Wilderness is Hansel and Gretel trope replete with the whole breadcrumbs, hunger, witch, Cannibalism themes.

@Freakonomics 20. Whether the Wilderness of the Mind was the will of Nature defines most ideology.

A conquering of this wilderness guides most of A.I. research and application.

@Freakonomics Nature, Wilderness, and Vanity:

Towards last years of living full time in India (05/6), I motorcycled a lot. Did 500mi trips where I romanticized wanderlust of man~machine~motion.

Che / Easy Rider influences.

Also peak premium mediocre amongst young Indian men. https://t.co/YipBs1uBtb

@Freakonomics 22.  Amongst the best writings I've encountered on motorcycling is via Melissa HolBrooke Pierson.

https://t.co/i2j7nODE3x

@Freakonomics 23. Nature, Wilderness, and Legibility:

Nature is a legible Wilderness.

Fear of illegibility drives most interpretations of "human progress" because it is where agency is conferred. 

What if progress implies staying wild / illegible? 

The wild is where agency is non-existent.

@Freakonomics 24. Case for staying Wild / It promotes Diversity.

A greening of the planet by massive tree monocultural planting has shown to be more harmful than just leaving be. 

aka Green Desserts.

https://t.co/86AJdsFZOC
@Freakonomics 25. Slums are the urban wilderness. https://t.co/lvys1QvzaO

@Freakonomics 26. Suburbs are orthogonal to Nature and Wilderness. 

The illusionary promise of solitarily sipping of your Nespresso while witnessing a sampling of nature is premium mediocre at it's peak.

@Freakonomics 27. While the wilderness is largely without agency, recluses are the agents of nature and wilderness. 

A nice example of a functioning recluse is the Wizard Radagast from LOTR. https://t.co/xxpvQWbGTc

@Freakonomics 28. Another recluse that intrigued me was the story of Hiroo Onoda who lived in the Philippine Jungles for 29 years after the surrender of WW2 Japan. Several attempts by the Japanese Govt to extract him failed because of his zealous loyalty. His story made me shiver. https://t.co/ZaI1K56aN1

@Freakonomics 31~The discovery of Piraha in the Brazilian jungles by former Pentecostal preacher and linguist~Daniel Everett~took on the foundation of Chomsky's law of recursion & language organ theory by showing evidence of a people that violated certain fundamentals of human language. HUGE! https://t.co/KLHDZahvse

@Freakonomics 33~Back to exiles for a bit. Teddy Roosevelt and his Ì†æÌ¥† years in Dakotas was foundational to not only his rise to the Presidency but also cement the place of Strongman~Conquer the Frontier Thesis in the American conscience. https://t.co/7VpIes3zQV

@Freakonomics 34~ Okay Feral Children.
Romulus & Remus were foundational to Rome.

Disney Mowgli :: Older Millennials

Jodie Foster, Nell :: intriguing, haunting movie. https://t.co/3uXi6BXChw

@Freakonomics 35~The Wild is usually associated with Ferocity which is a facet of aggression and masculinity.

Paternity in the wild, with a few exceptions, is largely unsympathetic.

Maternity defies our concept of wilderness. 

Maternity, whether feral or civilized is constant. https://t.co/l8HaabMW7k

@Freakonomics 36~Knowing of homosexuality in the wild was key towards shifting my juvenile attitudes towards understanding it vs fearing it and even loathing it.

(which admittedly I did for a while as a wimpy Indian kid).

@Freakonomics 37~There was a moment when my dad and I cremated my grandfather  (in the Hindu tradition). Prior to cremation, you leave the body out for a while and wait for an animal or two to peck at it. This symbolizes the liberation and assimilation of the spirit into nature.

@Freakonomics 38~The Parsis of Mumbai maintain the Doongerwadi aka The Towers of Silence where their dead are placed for vultures. There's a fascinating forensic story about how the introduction of Arthritis medicine created havoc for Mumbai's vulture population. https://t.co/w3mRqmYBbZ

@Freakonomics 39~Ayahuasca! and psychedelics are how the canonical edgy urbanized liberal intellectual interacts with Nature and Wilderness. The traditions of Shamanic healings operate on integrating our soul with nature's spirit. 

Oh and spirit animals! https://t.co/tGmphAGZxb

@Freakonomics 40~Declaring indigenous culture that incorporated Nature and Wilderness into faith as heresy was a key feature of Christian missionary movement, a necessary precursor for full-blown colonialism.

@Freakonomics 41~Werner Herzog's Aguirre, The Wrath of God is a powerful portrait of Christian Missionary Purpose, the Spanish monarchy, the Conquistador mandate brute forcing through the Amazon.

https://t.co/2cfNOEIfNM

@Freakonomics 42~ooh feral superheros! 

George of the Jungle Ì†ΩÌ∏Ç
TARZAN!
THE PHANTOM!
Black Panther!

I don't (and should) know more feral women superheroines (Catwoman maybe)...

https://t.co/qrVAPjzb6x

@Freakonomics 44~Biomimickry copies natural elegance onto useful things. 

What does copying wildness / ferality yield? Resilience perhaps. 

Antifragility has a feral element to it that makes things inherently resilient.

Vines and Weeds come to mind. https://t.co/zj0wV4lipM

@Freakonomics 45~"Wild"Ì†ΩÌ¥• across the planet signal the arrival of the Pyroxene. 

They cause us to turn off our grids~orrupts the air we breathe~making aboveground living unbearable. 

The ferality of wildfires makes them that much more dangerous

https://t.co/hQL9Pe1fSe

@Freakonomics 47~Planet of the Apes was when the "personified" Wild turned on us and flip the tables on us bringing out our collective Wild side.

It's a fantastic tale of the unintended result of our hubris in trying to tame the wild. https://t.co/wvgWV3t90h

@Freakonomics 48~Reign of Fire is another telling of the Wild turning on us. This time it's Dragons. 

Pretty underrated and enjoyable watching.

Kinda also shows the flaws of toxic masculinity (McConaughey plays it good)

https://t.co/7TM3BDEsV2

@Freakonomics 49~To see something "in the wild" is to witness it in its natural state. 

Do we witness humanity in the wild?

"Natural" acts of kindness / cruelty / faith / intelligence / prediction sub-conscious ..... ?

Seems oxymoronic/uncanny and it shouldn't be, right?

@Freakonomics 50~ To Nudge is orthogonal to Nature <> Nurture.

Nature implies a complete lack of individual agency.

Nurture, the opposite.

To Nudge is to be guided without agency.

What are we all being nudged towards without our explicit consent?
@Freakonomics 51~ "It's in their Nature" can be interpreted as absolute agency or a complete lack thereof...like Instinct does not involve explicit decisions.

@Freakonomics 52~Ayuverveda, an old form of Indian natural medicine defines 3 root constitutions ("natures") of all human physiology.

Pitta :: Of fire 
Vata :: Of Air
Kapha :: Of the Ground

Everyone has an imbalance of some of the 3 and the point is to use Ayurveda to strike a balance.

@Freakonomics 54~Kaphas are slow-moving turtle like energy profiles. Their skins tend to be oily and overall unctuous personalities. 

I stay away from these people as they are kryptonite. https://t.co/VVDOi9JtwM

@Freakonomics 55~Instinct is the agency (or lack thereof) of the Nature and Wilderness ! 

I've always marvelled at Instinct.

It's memory transmitted through DNA.

Evolution is largely superficial but Instinct seems, perhaps wrongly, to represent so much more, it's a hardwiring of neurons.

@Freakonomics 56~Structuration theory classifies Society as a function of Structure and Agency.

Does that imply that Nature and the Wilderness is anything that's devoid of Structure and Agency?

That which is formless, timeless, and mindless?

Yeah sounds about right. https://t.co/Q0NPCjqjXW

@Freakonomics 57~The aesthetics (smell,sound,taste,sight) of Nature and the Wild are distinct.

Nature: elegant, coherent, soothing
The Wild: Raw, Disturbing

Reminds me of Keats' double-entendre : "Beauty is Truth, Truth Beauty"

Is what is BeautifulÌ†ΩÌ¥ÅTrue?

@Freakonomics 58~Nature& Wilderness as instrument of premium mediocre fascism. Exhibit 1 : Modi's tryst with Bear Gryllis an attempt to transplant Americana frontier myth onto Hindu Indian males to relive some version of reverence to nature as a proxy for vain virility

https://t.co/ycC5VEe3p9

@Freakonomics 59~Putin kinda sorta started the trend. 

playbook being : let me demonstrate my virility to the men of my country and they'll all fall in place. https://t.co/Wko60RqNxR

@Freakonomics 60~Wild Horse fetish from the potentate of Turkmenistan courtesy John Oliver.

https://t.co/8xdzqWROPZ
